awd_titl_txt: REU Site in Interdisciplinary Materials Research
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The REU Site at Southern Illinois University Carbondale will provide research opportunities for an average of 14 undergraduates per year (including 2 supported internally) for a 9 week period each summer. Students will be involved in interdisciplinary projects in the broadly defined area of materials research. Inclusion of faculty mentors from various disciplines (Chemistry, Physics, Engineering, Microbiology, and the Materials Technology Center) will enable the REU students to develop skills needed to excel in both academic and industrial research environments, where interdisciplinary teams are standard and researchers must communicate effectively across disciplines. Students will also be required to think about the application of their research to new technologies and the manufacturing of new devices, and will have the opportunity to present their results to a diverse audience. The Site will recruit primarily from 2-/4-year institutions residing in neighboring states or the Mississippi Delta region, as well as those with traditionally high enrollment of students from underrepresented groups. Students participating in this Site will learn to network with other scientists and engineers through various social activities including weekly lunches with faculty mentors and weekend trips to cultural, industrial, and recreational locations. Primary goals of the site include: (1) creating a positive image of science and engineering as a career choice. Students will leave the program with a greater sense of the trials, tribulations, and rewards that await them; (2) providing a nurturing environment and instilling a sense of confidence in the art of discussing and practicing science; (3) improving the participants? oral and written communication skills; (4) teaching of basic research tools, including literature searches and the operation of modern instrumentation; (5) fostering a collaborative teamwork approach to research; and (6) increasing the number of domestic students, especially those from underrepresented groups, who choose to pursue STEM careers. A detailed assessment plan will be followed to enable evaluation of our efforts. 

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The mentored research projects associated with this Site promise to be excellent training grounds for working in materials and related fields. Students will be exposed to a variety of transformative projects at the forefront of science and engineering, including: (1) studies related to the synthesis of advanced functional materials (metal organic frameworks, inorganic heterostructures, thin films, nanocomposites, novel electron-accepting materials; electrospun nanofibers, nanoscale/microscale heterogeneous catalysts, etc.); (2) materials characterization (via electron microscopies, solid- and solution-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, optical/magnetic transport measurements, ultraviolet/visible/infrared/two-dimensional-infrared/Raman spectroscopies, etc.); (3) theoretical/computational studies (wherein students will learn how to study materials via density functional theory calculations, molecular dynamics simulations, etc.); and (4) materials applications varying from energy storage and photovoltaics, to biosensors and contrast agents, to polymer lithography for device fabrication. 

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The demands of industrial and academic research drive the development of improved ways to train students. It is not uncommon to find teams of researchers with diverse interdisciplinary backgrounds that are working together to solve a common problem. The activities undertaken in this NSF-REU program is to provide such interdisciplinary research and training  activities in the field of Materials Science and drew its strength from several core disciplines such as Chemistry, Physics, Mechanical Engineering, Biochemistry/Molecular Biology, Computing etc. Delivering the understanding of basic science as well as the impact of this understanding in developing applications (ranging from nano-electronics to remediation of microplastics)--to a generation of students in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines, was one of the principal foci of the program.

The Broader Impacts of this Site were manifold. Through this program we were able to  enable the participation of undergraduate students--particularly those from underrepresented groups and 2-/4-year institutions with little or no major research infrastructure or opportunities--in mentored research. We were able to encourage the participants to choose STEM-based career paths, gave opportunities for the broad dissemination of scientific results via student-co-authored technical publications/conference presentations, and provided interdisciplinary training for next-generation students/workforce. Some specific outcomes are summarized below.

Recruitment Outcomes: For our most recent three-year cycle (including one year of NCE where our program was postponed because of our University's response to the covid-19 pandemic), ~43.2% (19) were female, ~54.5% (24) were male, and ~2.2% (1) were gender-non-binary. ~30% were from underrepresented minority groups, a number that grows to over 36% when other types of underrepresented students are included (e.g. female physicists/engineers). Nearly 70% of participants were from our targeted institutions in the region (IL, IN, MO, KY, WI, IA, & TN), Mississippi Delta region, select HBCUs, high minority-enrollment institutions, and junior colleges (from within and outside this targeted region); nevertheless, the relatively large number of applicants from outside our list of targeted schools likely indicates that our REU program is being proactively sought out by students using the internet.

The recruitment outcomes for the past 16 years and their assessment in terms of our Program's original goals may be found in Figure 1. Overall, we are pleased with the process and results of the recruitment during these years of the program. The numbers of strong, qualified candidates was more than sufficient for us to routinely construct an excellent cohort of participants. Indeed, for the candidates who accepted our offer (yield generally ~50%), the numbers of participants who were from underrepresented groups, female participants, external participants, participants from targeted schools / regions, and students from non-PhD granting schools exceeded our goals in most cases and nearly met our goals in most of the remaining cases.

Assessment of Student Outcomes. The consensus of the participating faculty was that the recruited students were high quality and possessed great potential as future scientists and researchers (at least according to all feedback received by the PI/Co-PI). All participants completed their oral presentation, their poster and poster presentation, and final research report, and completed (e.g. instrumentation) training associated with their  projects (as well as lab safety and scientific ethics training). However, arguably the most important outcome, in our opinion, from this program so far is that over 74% of our REU alumni (sampling participant years 2009-2019) are on STEM career tracks, including 39 currently enrolled in science/engineering grad school, and 69 that have employment in STEM fields) (Fig. 2). We also note that 11 of the participants who have gone onto graduate school have chosen graduate programs here at SIUC - in addition to 3 junior-college transfers into our undergraduate program.  So, far according to our knowledge we have at least 10 PhD REU alums.

Research Outcomes. All REU participants presented their research in poster form at our annual summer undergraduate research symposium (this year well-attended by ~100 scientists and students) and summarize their work in the final written report, our program also actively encourages its participants to participate in public dissemination of their research results, and towards this end provides financial support for attending and presenting their work at research conferences across the country.

To date we can report 2 more peer reviewed publications which will make a total of 16 publications in this cycle (in addition to 50 peer reviewed publications and 1 patent from the previous cycles). This means that we will have 66 peer-reviewed journal articles from all other previous cycles, (2006 - 2021). Another 2 articles are under review. Similarly, we can report 4 more conference presentations (~29 in this cycle), taking our total conference presentation to 111 (from all other previous cycles, 2006 - 2021), where REU students have been listed as co-authors or co-presenters. A large number (>50 different) REU participants have been listed as co-authors and/or co-presenters so far in the above-mentioned publications/presentations/patents (2006-2021)..
